Hearing.Statement: <opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. ROBERT E. LATTA, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF OHIO</opening> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Again, good morning, and welcome to our witnesses today. We are very glad to have you with us today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Today, we continue the Disrupter Series examining FinTech and all the ways that entrepreneurs and established businesses are looking to give consumers more tools and control over their finances.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Families across the country strive to achieve financial independence and stability. Many no longer feel certain that their children will be better off than they were at their age, a change from just a few years ago.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Understanding how new technology can assist families in managing their finances, especially while on the go, is a conversation we need to have.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Improving consumers' financial options is a clear example of the new technology pushing and disrupting established industries.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">While we must focus on protecting the consumers, it is also important that we keep an eye on what matters to the consumer-- what are their goals, what motivates them to use one service over another.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">How can we encourage innovation while keeping the consumer protection bar high? In this conversation about improving access to commerce it is important to remember that there are generally three relationships people have with traditional institutions.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">People have access to all the traditional financial services; second, the underbanked who have a checking account and maybe a savings account but also use alternative financial services like rent-to-own services or auto title loans; and third, the 7 percent of Americans who are unbanked, who do not have a checking or savings account and how use alternative services.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">There are a number of statistics demonstrating how large the opportunity is to reach more Americans with relevant services. Twenty percent of the U.S. population--over 60 percent of Americans--are underbanked or unbanked.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Sixty-four percent of Americans earning less than $30,000 per year own a smart phone, and finally, over $12 billion were invested in FinTech companies in 2016.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">Increasingly, Americans are turning to online and mobile banking, according to a 2015 study from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. Over 31 percent of Americans used mobile banking and that number has likely risen in the last 2 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">There are tremendous opportunities for companies to reach consumers with new products to help them create a rainy day fund for the first time, securely pay their mortgage, rebuild their credit budget, manage multiple income streams and invest their earnings.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">One of the first questions that come to mind in any conversation about money is security. Cybersecurity is an ongoing challenge and one the Energy and Commerce Committee is tackling head on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">At this time, one of our other subcommittees in the Energy and Commerce is getting ready to start a hearing focused on healthcare cybersecurity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">In this subcommittee we have discussed how cybersecurity plays in development and life cycle of a number of connected devices through the Disrupter Series.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">While there is no silver bullet, we do need to keep cybersecurity at the top of our minds because if consumers do not trust the products and services they use are secure then they will not use them.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="HON. ROBERT E. LATTA">I would like to thank our witnesses for joining us today and I look forward to your perspectives on how we can ensure that innovation in the FinTech space continues in the United States, how innovation can improve consumer protection and how the regulatory environment has impacted innovation.</paragraph>

<opening>Prepared statement of Hon. Robert E. Latta</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">Again, I want to thank all of our witnesses for rejoining us today for this very important discussion that we will have.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">Good morning and welcome to the Digital Commerce and Consumer Protection subcommittee hearing. Today we continue the Disrupter Series examining FinTech and all of the ways that entrepreneurs and established businesses are looking to give consumers more tools and control over their finances.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">Financial independence and stability is the goal for so many families across this country. People no longer feel certain that their children will be better off than they were at their age--a change from just a few years ago. Understanding how new technology can be leveraged responsibly to give people on-the-go control over their finances is a critical conversation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">Improving consumer's financial options is a clear example of where new technology is going to push and disrupt established industries. As much as consumer protection is focused on protecting, we also need to keep our eye on the consumer too. What are their goals? What motivates them to use one service over another? How can we encourage innovation while keeping the consumer protection bar high?</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">In this conversation about improving consumers access to commerce, it is important to remember that there are generally three relationships people may have with traditional institutions:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Hon. Latta"><bullet> The underbanked, who have a checking account, and maybe a savings account, but also use alternative financial services like rent-to-own services or auto title loans; and,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> The 7 percent of Americans who are unbanked--who do not have a checking or savings account and only use alternative services.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">There are a number of statistics demonstrating how large the opportunity is to reach more Americans with relevant services:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> 20 percent of the U.S. population, over 60 million Americans, are underbanked or unbanked.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> 64 percent of Americans earning less than $30,000 per year own a smartphone.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> Finally, over $12 billion was invested in FinTech companies in 2016.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">Increasingly Americans are turning to online and mobile banking. According to the most recent study from the FDIC (Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation), over 31 percent of Americans use mobile banking and that number has likely risen in the last 2 years.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">There are serious opportunities for companies to reach consumers with new products to help them create a rainy-day fund for the first time, make faster more secure payments, rebuild their credit, budget and manage multiple income streams, and invest.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">One of the first questions that comes to mind in any conversation about money is security. Cybersecurity is an ongoing challenge, and one the Energy and Commerce Committee is tackling head on. Upstairs, our sister subcommittee is getting ready to start a hearing focused on health care cybersecurity. Throughout the Disrupter Series, we have discussed how cybersecurity plays into development and the lifecycle of a number of connected devices. There is no silver bullet. We need to keep cybersecurity top of mind, because if consumers do not trust that the products and services they use are secure, then they will not use them. Plain and simple.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta">I would like to thank our witnesses for joining us today and I look forward to your perspectives on:</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> How we can ensure that innovation in the FinTech space continues in the United States,</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> how innovation can improve consumer protection, and</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"><bullet> how the regulatory environment has impacted innovation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Hon. Robert E. Latta"> Thank you all for joining us today for this important discussion. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Latta</speaker>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. JANICE D. SCHAKOWSKY, AREPRESENTATIVE IN CONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF ILLINOIS</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. JANICE D. SCHAKOWSKY"> And at this time, I'd like to recognize the gentlelady from Illinois, the ranking member of the subcommittee for 5 minutes for an opening statement. Good morning. </paragraph> <speaker>Ms. Schakowsky</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">Good morning. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">Today, in the subcommittee, we are going to be looking into the potential to provide consumers better options through financial technology, or FinTech.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">On the floor this afternoon, the House will be debating legislation to gut existing consumer protections for financial products. These discussions can't happen in isolation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">Consumers can only realize the full benefit of FinTech if we have reasonable safeguards in place to prevent abusive practices, secure personal information and protect consumers from fraud.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">The Financial CHOICE Act, what my Democratic colleagues and I call the Wrong Choice Act, puts those safeguards in severe jeopardy.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">One of the landmark achievements of the Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform Consumer Protection Act was the creation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">The CFPB is an effective consumer watchdog and it has returned $12 billion to 29 million harmed consumers. The Wrong Choice Act would gut this critical consumer watchdog. It would make it harder for the CFPB to take action to protect consumers.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">It would threaten the CPB's funding. It would specifically block the CFPB from pursuing consumer protections in areas like payday lending and it would block the CFPB's proposed rule limiting arbitration to ensure that consumers can defend their rights in court.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="10" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">Who benefits? Not consumers. Not responsible businesses. The winners are big banks like Wells Fargo that open up fraudulent accounts for their customers, pay lenders that trap consumers in unaffordable debt, credit card companies that engage in deceptive practices, for-profit colleges that prey on veterans and reverse mortgage companies that put seniors' homes at risk.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="11" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">The CFPB has proven time and time again that it is a research and data-driven agency. It has been actively engaged in exploring how FinTech can be part of consumer-friendly innovation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="12" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">In October, the CFPB released its Project Catalyst Report on Innovation in Financial Services. The report highlighted the tremendous potential for FinTech to improve the lives of Americans. It also emphasized the importance of building consumer protections into new innovations from the outset.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="13" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">Effective protections need to be flexible enough to apply to new financial products. That's precisely what the CFPB did in its rule for prepaid products.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="14" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">It requires protections against fraud and unauthorized charges as well as basic transparency regarding fees and balances.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="15" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">The rules apply to both physical prepaid cards and mobile wallets because consumers deserve strong protections whether they are swiping cards or using smart phones.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="16" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">I believe the CFPB's valuable work should continue. I choose consumers over unethical companies that engage in unfair, deceptive and abusive practices.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="17" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">I will be voting against the Wrong Choice Act this afternoon. If my colleagues really care about providing quality financial options for American consumers, they will do the same.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="18" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">With proper protections baked in, I believe FinTech will have great benefit for consumers. It provides new opportunities to reach the unbanked and underbanked households. FinTech companies have already made it easier than ever to make person- to-person payments.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="19" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">We will be hearing much more from our witnesses about some of the specific innovations that FinTech companies are working on.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="20" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">And as with other topics in our Disrupter Series, the policy challenge for this subcommittee to consider is how we adapt today's rules to tomorrow's technology.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="21" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky">I look forward to hearing the insight from our panelists as we continue efforts to make sure consumers can truly benefit from the promise of new innovation.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="22" speaker="Ms. Schakowsky"> And I yield back. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Latta</speaker> <paragraph paraId="23" speaker="Mr. Latta">Thank you. The gentlelady yields back.</paragraph>

<opening>OPENING STATEMENT OF HON. GREG WALDEN, A REPRESENTATIVE INCONGRESS FROM THE STATE OF OREGON</opening> <paragraph paraId="1" speaker="HON. GREG WALDEN"> At this time, the Chair now recognizes the gentleman from Oregon, the chairman of the full committee, for his opening statement. Good morning. </paragraph> <speaker>Mr. Walden</speaker> <paragraph paraId="2" speaker="Mr. Walden">Good morning. Thank you, Mr. Chairman, and welcome to our panelists and to our guests today.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="3" speaker="Mr. Walden">Today's Disrupter Series takes an important look at how we can ensure that innovation's improving options and outcomes for consumers and their financial health by way of financial technology, more commonly known as FinTech.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="4" speaker="Mr. Walden">Smart phone adoption has skyrocketed in recent years which provides a new platform to reach consumers with basic services such as online banking or more complex transactions like mortgage applications.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="5" speaker="Mr. Walden">In Oregon where I come from, the percentage of people unbanked or underbanked is slightly higher than the national average.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="6" speaker="Mr. Walden">So if there is an opportunity to help folks engage in commerce, start a savings account, become more financially secure, we should be giving it serious consideration and FinTech could provide that opportunity.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="7" speaker="Mr. Walden">Disruption or change can be uncomfortable. But if we remain focused on the consumer and what is in the best interests of the consumer we can move forward productively.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="8" speaker="Mr. Walden">Startups, incumbents and partnerships are all critical components of this conversation. Now, ultimately we know that if consumers do not find something useful, they won't use it, given the choice.</paragraph> <paragraph paraId="9" speaker="Mr. Walden">The reality is that consumers are demanding better, faster, more secure services in every industry.
